 how come basketball is not the most popular game of the world? it only takes a basket, a pole, a small court and 10 players?
 

 
 Actually, basketball has become VERY popular around the world. There are professional basketball leagues in Europe and it is going wild in China. 
 

 Is Basketball Slowly Replacing Soccer As Top Global Sport?
 
 
 The English Premier League (EPL) is the "embodiment of sporting globalisation," but in recent years the popularity of soccer has "plummeted, taking down with it the sport's leading brand," the EPL, in favor of basketball and the NBA, according to Julian Borger of the Manchester GUARDIAN. The "meteoric rise of basketball in China almost certainly means basketball has now surpassed [soccer] as the world's leading sport, in terms of the number of active players." The success of basketball in China represents "one of the most stunning marketing coups of our time." Fourteen NBA games are broadcast live every week on state TV and 51 regional stations in the country. In January, the NBA set up four offices in China. The contrast with the EPL's fortunes "could not be starker," as the league "does not have an office or a single representative in Beijing." But "a lot of this is not" of the EPL's making, as "some of it is due to chance." Borger: "We are now in the midst of a second round of sporting globalisation. It is a more voluntary affair, requiring willing sellers and willing buyers, so Britain's sporting exports are facing much stiffer competition." It is "not enough for today's professional clubs, leagues and associations to collect subscriptions and ticket receipts -- like any other corporation, they must grow, and that ultimately means spilling over their borders" (Manchester GUARDIAN, 12/6).
 Is Basketball Slowly Replacing Soccer As Top Global Sport?
 

 

 how come baseball is not the most popular sport of the world? one ball a stick and some dummies standing still ?
 

 Baseball is also growing around the world. 
 

 Baseball goes global 
 America's game takes on world flavor as talent flows to majors 
 Friday, March 30, 2001 
 By JIM CAPLE
 SEATTLE POST-INTELLIGENCER REPORTER 
 Not all that long ago, baseball's so-called major leagues were limited to U.S. cities east of the Mississippi or along its western banks. Baseball's idea of internationalism was nicknaming someone Dutch or Heinie. 
 No longer. Baseball may be on the decline in U.S. inner cities, but it is expanding across the globe as steadily and surely as Mo Vaughn's waistline. Foreign-born players made up 24 percent of major league opening day rosters last year, with 198 players representing 16 countries and Puerto Rico. Two years ago, baseball opened its season in Mexico. Last year, it opened in Japan. This year, it opens in Puerto Rico. 
 
 Baseball has more of an international flavor than a shelf of Starbucks high-priced exotic blends. When the Expos and Japanese pitcher Hideki Irabu played the Dodgers and Korean pitcher Chan Ho Park the first week of last season, fans could listen to the game in English, Spanish, French, Japanese and Korean. 
 This spring the Mariners had players from Japan, Korea, the Dominican Republic, Venezuela, Canada, Australia, Colombia, Aruba, Nicaragua, Panama, Mexico, Puerto Rico, China and even Italy -- can't wait for that Francesco Imperiali baseball card -- in their major and minor league camps. 
 How far has baseball extended its borders? 
 "The Mariners have a scout in Europe. Imagine that," Mariners CEO Howard Lincoln said. 
 And not just Europe. The Mariners have either part-time or full-time scouts in Korea, Taiwan, China and Australia, and obviously also keep a close watch on players in Japan. Nor are they alone. The Mets have had a full-time scout in Japan for five years. 
 "There are numerous teams that never had a face in the Pacific Rim before that realize they have to have a presence there now, even if it's just following the guys we scout," said Ted Heid, Mariners director of Pacific Rim scouting. 
 In time, the World Series could be truly and exactly that. 
 Baseball goes global

 Not to be insulting, but do you even understand the rules of football? Do you know the player positions, the strategy, why there are stoppages in action and why the clock doesn't always run, etc? Do you have any ties to a particular football team? (For example, I hate the NBA, but I follow college basketball because I have a team.) I couldn't care less about rugby or cricket, but that's because I don't know the players, I don't know the teams, I don't know the rules or strategy, etc. 
 
 Also, neither of teams who were in the Super Bowl this year have cheerleaders (and they have two of the largest fanbases in American sports), so your hypothesis is incorrect.
 
 Now soccer... there's a boring sport. I could just as easily say that soccer is just a ton of guys on a ridiculously large field jogging around and constantly turning the ball over, rarely scoring, getting elementary-school-esque colored cards for discipline, ridiculously flailing and exaggerating any contact, and playing while the clock counts up. Seriously... as a kid I never knew how long a soccer game or how much time was left because the clock didn't count down. But even still, I can understand the tradition, the pride, the excitement, and all that for soccer and the World Cup and all that.
